'''Nathan Mantel''' (February 16, 1919 – May 26, 2002) was an American [[biostatistician]] best known for his work with William Haenszel which led to the [[Cochran–Mantel–Haenszel statistics|Mantel–Haenszel test]] and its associated estimate, the Mantel–Haenszel [[odds ratio]]. The Mantel–Haenszel procedure and its extensions allow data from several sources or groups to be combined while avoiding [[confounding]].<ref>{{Citation
 | author = Mantel, N.
 | coauthors = Haenszel, W.
 | year = 1959
 | title = Statistical aspects of the analysis of data from the retrospective analysis of disease
 | journal = Journal of the National Cancer Institute
 | volume = 22
 | pages = 719–748
 | pmid = 13655060
 | issue = 4
 | postscript = .
 | doi=10.1093/jnci/22.4.719
}}</ref>

He spent much of his career working for the [[National Cancer Institute]]. During his, career he published over 380 academic papers. Later in his life, Mantel was known for defending the [[tobacco industry]] against claims that [[passive smoking]] was harmful.<ref>{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Woods |title=‘Passive Smoking’ Report is Disputed |newspaper=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |date=July 18, 1981 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=19810718&id=joNIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AG4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6763,3133468 }}</ref>
